intro: Galium aparinoides, commonly known as creeping bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial herb native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate or ascending stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic, and covered with fine hairs. Galium aparinoides thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodland floors and stream banks.
